The Iwato scale uses intervals that are not part of the equal temperament system, which is standard in Western music. The twelve-tone technique relies on the chromatic scale, which is equally tempered, meaning each semitone is the same interval apart. The Iwato scale, however, uses intervals that are based on the natural harmonic series and are not equally spaced. This difference in tuning could make it difficult to integrate the Iwato scale into a twelve-tone composition, which requires precise control over all twelve notes.

Another angle to consider is whether the twelve-tone technique allows for the use of any scale or if it's strictly about the arrangement of all twelve notes.
